The earliest Matsushita goods ended up being extremely popular since they were of higher quality with a reduced cost. These founding principles are alive in Panasonic in the present day with superior quality electronic devices with premium abilities but no premium price tag.
;
;Following The Second World War, Panasonic expanded dramatically. Panasonic merchandise, particularly the transistor radios soon became internationally renowned. Exports to the United States escalated at a fast pace as Panasonic established manufacturing plants world wide. Matsushita 1st launched U.S. offices in New York City in 1959 as Matsushita Electric Corporation of America (MECA). Panasonic’s rapid advancement attracted worldwide attention and in 1961, Panasonic’s founder, Konosuke Matsushita in fact made the cover of Time Magazine.
;
;Since then, Panasonic continues to be a leader in technological know-how. Panasonic has had plasma TVs which were often the largest commercially available. Panasonic "1sts" in the plasma HDTV market place range from the 1st seventy inch plasma, the first 103" plasma and now has a 152" plasma TV.
